intro: Physalis chamaesarachoides var. multiflorifer, commonly known as the Mexican groundcherry, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Mexico. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes and potatoes, and is characterized by its distinctive inflated calyces that enclose the fruit. The plant produces small, yellow-orange berries that are edible when ripe. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often growing in dry, rocky environments. Its botanical features make it a unique and ornamental addition to gardens.
